answer:
1. Frame‐by‐Frame Analysis:  
   • Frame 1 and Frame 2:  The flagger’s paddle faces traffic with the unmistakable red, octagonal “STOP” side showing. Vehicles approaching appear to be halted.  
   • Frame 3:  The worker begins to transition the sign. The “STOP” side is no longer fully facing oncoming traffic; instead, you can see hints of the reflective orange surfacing for “SLOW.”  
   • Frame 4 and Frame 5:  The paddle clearly displays the orange “SLOW” side toward traffic, indicating drivers may proceed carefully.  

2. Contextual Reasoning:  
   The sequence of images shows a typical flagger operation in a construction zone: initially “STOP” to hold traffic, then rotating the paddle to “SLOW” so that vehicles may pass with caution.  

3. Match to Answer Choices:  
   • A. Stop to slow – This matches the observed progression in the frames: the sign goes from fully “STOP” facing traffic to “SLOW.”  
   • B. Slow to stop – This is the reverse of what is shown.  
   • C. Stop to yield – The paddle is not switched to “YIELD” but to “SLOW.”  
   • D. Yield to slow – The first side shown is not “YIELD,” so this does not match.  

4. Provide the Best Answer:  
   Based on the transition visible across the frames, the paddle sign changes from “STOP” to “SLOW.”  

<answer>A. Stop to slow</answer>
